text: Dui Finn, son of Sétna Innarraid, was, according to medieval Irish legend and historical tradition, a High King of Ireland. He took power after killing his predecessor, and his father's killer, Siomón Brecc. He ruled for ten years, before he was killed by Siomón's son Muiredach Bolgrach. The Lebor Gabála Érenn synchronises his reign with those of Xerxes I (485–465 BC) and Artaxerxes I (465–424 BC) of Persia.R. A. Stewart Macalister (ed. & trans.), Lebor Gabála Érenn: The Book of the Taking of Ireland Part V, Irish Texts Society, 1956, p. 253 The chronology of Geoffrey Keating's Foras Feasa ar Éirinn dates his reign to 679–674 BCBC,Geoffrey Keating, Foras Feasa ar Éirinn 1.26 that of the Annals of the Four Masters to 904–894 BC.Annals of the Four Masters M4296-4306 ==References== Category:Legendary High Kings of Ireland
title: Dui Finn
